 Federal Court 
 
 Mosley, J. 
 
 March 14, 2008. 
 
 
 
 Counsel: 
 
 Leonard H. Borenstein, for the applicant; 
 
 Ada Mok, for the respondent. 
 
 
 
 Solicitors of Record: 
 
 Leonard H. Borenstein, Toronto, Ontario, for the applicant; 
 
 John H. Sims, Q.C., Deputy Attorney General of Canada, Toronto, Ontario, for the respondent. 
 
 
 
 Summary: 
 
 This case is unedited, therefore contains no summary. Any footnotes found in this case will appear below end of document.

[1] 
   
 Mosley, J. 
 : Mr. Huang is a 27 year old Chinese citizen who claims to fear persecution by the Chinese authorities due to his membership in an underground Christian church which was raided on June 25, 2006, while he was not present. This application is for judicial review of the decision of the Refugee Protection Division (RPD), dated May 29, 2007, that he was neither a Convention refugee nor a person in need of protection.

[2] 
  The applicant is from a rural area and has a grade seven education. He worked in the rice fields or on fishing boats. On July 8, 2005, the fishing boat Mr. Huang and his uncle were on was hit by a larger vessel, which accident sent Mr. Huang to hospital and killed his uncle. He states that he became depressed and, after some time, joined an underground church at the instigation of a friend. He describes a small church whose members treated him as family and helped him to overcome his depression.

[3] 
  On June 25, 2006, after three and a half months' membership in the church, Mr. Huang claims it was raided by the Chinese authorities and six members of the congregation were arrested. Mr. Huang had not been present at the service, as he was caring for his ill mother. He was alerted by the friend who had initially introduced him to the church, and who had managed to escape the raid.

[4] 
  Mr. Huang fled to a friend's house, and learned from his mother that the authorities had searched his family's home on June 26th, ordering him to report by June 30th. On July 1st, they returned to look for him again, as he had remained in hiding. The friend with whom he had been staying helped him to find a "snakehead" or human trafficker and he fled to Canada, arriving July 14, 2006.

[5] 
  After a hearing on May 14, 2007 with the aid of an interpreter, the Panel found that Mr. Huang was not credible as a member of an underground Christian church as he had insufficient knowledge of Christianity, citing several specific instances of failure to know the details of Christian tenets.

[6] 
  While the applicant raised several issues, it is my view that the main issue raised in this application is whether the RPD was unreasonable in finding that the applicant was not credible in claiming to be a Christian.

[7] 
  This hearing was conducted prior to the judgment of the Supreme Court in  
  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  [2008] S.C.J. 9 which modified the standards on which judicial reviews are to be conducted. The review of an RPD finding of credibility prior to that decision was to be assessed on a patent unreasonableness standard.  
 Dunsmuir 
  eliminates the distinction between reasonableness  
 simpliciter 
  and patent unreasonableness. I will, therefore, assess whether the decision of the RPD was unreasonable. I note that, in the instant case, the change in standards of review does not alter the outcome I would have reached prior to  
 Dunsmuir 
 .

[8] 
  The applicant submits that the Board's finding was based on unattainable and unreasonable requirements for knowledge of the Christian faith. The applicant had, at the time of the hearing, been exposed to Christianity for just over a year. He showed a reasonable level of knowledge of the faith in those circumstances. The applicant also asserts that his level of knowledge of Christianity should not be a determinative factor in an assessment of whether he is indeed a Christian.

[9] 
  The respondent contends that the applicant bore the burden of proving his claim, based on his alleged religious beliefs. He was unable to show that he possessed a reasonable familiarity with the services of the underground church or even a basic grasp of Christianity. The Board member supported her findings with ample reasons and her decision should not be vacated.

[10] 
  Mr. Huang is a young man with little education, who was raised in a country where the Christian faith is not part of the social fabric. From the transcript of the hearing, it is clear that his few points of error on doctrinal issues are vastly outweighed by his knowledge of the Christian faith. The RPD appears to have been overly focused on those few points of error or misunderstandings to a level which reached the microscopic analysis criticized in  
  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  and subsequent cases.

[11] 
  The Board member's standard for knowledge of Christian doctrine was unrealistically high, and she was clearly weighing his description of a standard service at the underground church against her own idea of how a service unfolds. I cannot find her decision reasonable, given the personal circumstances of the applicant and his evidence.

[12] 
  For these reasons, the decision of the RPD is vacated and Mr. Huang's case is to be assessed by a differently constituted Panel. Neither party proposed a question for certification. 
 
 
 
 JUDGMENT

[13] 
   
 IT IS THE JUDGMENT OF THIS COURT that 
  this application is allowed. No questions are certified. 
 
 
 
 [End of document]

legal_issues: The standard of review applicable to decisions regarding refugee status claims, specifically concerning credibility assessments.
Whether a refugee claimant’s level of religious knowledge is a determinative factor in assessing the genuineness of their religious beliefs and persecution claim.
The reasonableness of an administrative body’s assessment of a claimant’s credibility when the claimant has limited education and recent exposure to the claimed belief system.
The appropriate scope of inquiry into a claimant’s understanding of religious doctrine in the context of a refugee claim based on religious persecution.
Whether an administrative decision is unreasonable when it focuses disproportionately on minor errors in a claimant’s understanding of complex concepts.
factual_background: A 27-year-old Chinese citizen applied for judicial review of a refugee claim denial.
The applicant claimed fear of persecution due to membership in an underground Christian church.
The church was raided by Chinese authorities on June 25, 2006, resulting in the arrest of six members; the applicant was not present.

Prior to joining the church, the applicant worked in agriculture and experienced a traumatic event involving a fishing boat accident in July 2005, resulting in the death of his uncle and his own hospitalization.
The applicant joined the church after the accident, seeking support for depression.
Following the raid, the applicant was alerted by a friend and learned authorities searched his home on June 26th and sought him on July 1st.
The applicant fled China with the assistance of a human trafficker, arriving in Canada on July 14, 2006.
The Refugee Protection Division (RPD) denied the applicant's claim, citing insufficient knowledge of Christianity during a hearing on May 14, 2007.

Applicants: The RPD’s finding was based on unattainable and unreasonable requirements for knowledge of the Christian faith.
The applicant demonstrated a reasonable level of knowledge of Christianity given his limited exposure (just over a year).
The applicant’s level of knowledge of Christianity should not be the determinative factor in assessing his faith.
The RPD focused on minor errors in doctrinal understanding to an excessive degree (microscopic analysis).
Respondents: The applicant bore the burden of proving his claim based on his alleged religious beliefs.
The applicant was unable to demonstrate a reasonable familiarity with the services of the underground church.
The applicant lacked a basic grasp of Christianity.
The Board member provided ample reasons for her findings, and the decision should not be vacated.

court_analysis: The central issue was whether the Refugee Protection Division (RPD) acted unreasonably in finding the applicant, Mr. Huang, not credible regarding his claim of Christian faith and subsequent fear of persecution.

The court acknowledged the recent Supreme Court decision in *Dunsmuir* which altered the standard of review for judicial reviews, moving away from a distinction between reasonableness *simpliciter* and patent unreasonableness, and applying a single reasonableness standard. However, the court determined this change did not affect the outcome of this case.

The court found the RPD’s standard for demonstrating knowledge of Christian doctrine was “unrealistically high,” particularly given Mr. Huang’s limited education, rural background, and short exposure to Christianity (just over a year).

The court determined the RPD engaged in “microscopic analysis,” focusing excessively on minor errors in Mr. Huang’s understanding of Christian tenets while overlooking his overall demonstrated knowledge of the faith.

The court emphasized that Mr. Huang’s few errors were outweighed by his overall knowledge, considering his personal circumstances and the context of an underground church in China where the faith is not widely practiced.

The court found the RPD improperly compared Mr. Huang’s description of church services to the court member’s own expectations, rather than assessing his credibility based on the totality of the evidence.
Based on these findings, the court concluded the RPD’s decision was unreasonable and vacated it, ordering the case to be reassessed by a different panel.
final_outcome: The decision of the Refugee Protection Division is vacated.
The case is to be assessed by a differently constituted Panel.
